questions.text: A 68-year-old woman sustained a fracture of the proximal humerus and injured the axillary artery. She began bleeding into the fascia around it. Where is this fascia derived from?

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.solution:
The fascia around the axillary vessels and brachial plexus is called the axillary sheath. It is derived from the prevertebral fascia.

Clinical correlation:

  • In a brachial plexus nerve block, the axillary sheath localizes the anesthetic solution to the nerve plexus.
  • Chronic retropharyngeal abscess in TB may spread to the axilla or to the superior mediastinum. But it never spreads to the posterior mediastinum because prevertebral fascia fuses to restrict the spread.

questions.text: Identify the structure labelled in the diagram below.
questions.solution:
Structure labelled in the picture is artery piercing the clavipectoral fascia called thoracoacromial artery.

Clavipectoral fascia envelops the subclavius and pectoralis minor. Medially it forms the costocoracoid ligament. Laterally it is connected to the axillary fascia by suspensory ligament of axilla (Gerdy's ligament). The structures piercing clavipectoral fascia are:

  • 1 vein: Cephalic vein
  • 1 artery: Thoraco­acromial artery (associated veins and lymphatics)
  • 1 nerve: Lateral pectoral nerve.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe radicular pain of the upper extremity due to compression of the radial nerve in a space around the shoulder joint. Which of the following is false regarding this space?

choices.text: Superior border is by teres major
It contains the circumflex scapular vessels
Lateral border is by shaft of humerus
Medial border is by long head of triceps

questions.solution:
The space around the shoulder joint where the radial nerve may be compressed is the triangular interval. It contains the profunda brachii vessels.

Related Pearl: Spaces around shoulder joint

Space Boundaries Contents
Triangular space
(Upper triangular space)		 Superior Teres minor posteriorly
Subscapularis anteriorly		 Circumflex scapular vessels
Inferior Teres major
Lateral Long head of triceps
Triangular interval
(Lower triangular space)		 Superior Teres major posteriorly
Subscapularis anteriorly

Profunda brachii vessels

Radial nerve
Medial Long head of triceps
Lateral Humerus
Quadrangular space Superior Teres minor Posterior circumflex humeral vessels

Axillary nerve
Inferior Teres major
Medial Long head of triceps
Lateral Surgical neck of humerus

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with weakness of shoulder movements. Investigations revealed quadrangular space syndrome. Which of the following nerve is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The axillary nerve is likely to be affected as it is one of the contents of the quadrangular space.

Quadrangular space syndrome is a condition is caused by hypertrophy or fibrosis of the quadrangular space muscles which impinge on the axillary nerve. Patients present with weakness of the shoulder movements.

Related Pearl: Spaces around shoulder joint

Subscapularis anteriorly		 Circumflex scapular vessels

Subscapularis anteriorly

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of cubital fossa?
questions.solution:
Bicipital aponeurosis is not a content, it forms the roof of cubital fossa. Biceps tendon is a content of cubital fossa.

Note - The Radial nerve is given as content of the cubital fossa in some books, in others, it's excluded as a content of cubital fossa due to its extreme lateral position.

Historically, when blood-letting was practiced, the bicipital aponeurosis was known as the "grace of God" tendon as it protected important contents of the fossa (i.e. the brachial artery and the median nerve).

questions.text: A patient presented with tenderness in the region shown below following a fall onto an outstretched hand. Which of the following forms the roof of this region?
questions.solution:
The marked region is the anatomical snuffbox. The superficial branch of radial nerve forms the roof of the anatomical snuffbox. Tenderness in this region is suggestive of a scaphoid fracture, a common injury after a fall on an outstretched hand.

Anatomical snuffbox boundaries: 

Lateral wall:

  • Abductor pollicis longus (APL),
  • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)  

Medial wall:

  • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL).

Roof:

  • Cephalic vein
  • Superficial branch of radial nerve

Floor:

  • Radial styloid, Scaphoid, Trapezium, and 1st Metacarpal. 

Only content: Radial artery

The name "snuffbox" originates from the use of this surface for placing and then sniffing powdered tobacco, or snuff.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box?

choices.text: Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis

questions.solution:
The lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box is formed by extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus.

Boundaries of the anatomical snuffbox: 

  • Lateral wall:
    • Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
    • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)  
  • Medial wall:
    • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL)
  • Roof:
    • Cephalic vein
    • Superficial branch of the radial nerve
  • Floor:
    • Radial styloid, scaphoid, trapezium, and 1st metacarpal

Only content: Radial artery

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with tingling and numbness in her hands. The symptoms get worse at night and when she's at work using her computer. The affected structure contains all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of carpal tunnel syndrome. The carpal tunnel does not contain flexor carpi ulnaris tendon (FCU).

Carpal tunnel contents (10 structures): Also can be taken as 4 structures only if FDP and FDS are counted as 2 structures. 

  • Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP-4 tendons).
  • Flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS-4 tendons).
  • Flexor pollicis longus (FPL-1 tendon).
  • Median nerve between tendons of FDP and FDS.

Superficial to the carpal tunnel and the flexor retinaculum, the ulnar artery and ulnar nerve pass through the ulnar tunnel or Guyon's canal.

questions.text: Which among the following is false regarding flexor retinaculum or transverse carpal ligament?

choices.text: It is medially attached to pisiform and hook of hamate
It is laterally attached to scaphoid and trapezium
It splits into a medial superficial slip and a lateral deep slip
Flexor carpi radialis is the only content in the medial slip

questions.solution:
Flexor carpi radialis is the only content in the lateral slip, not medial slip.

Flexor retinaculum (carpal tunnel): 10 structures in total.  

  • 4 tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS), 4 tendons of flexor digitorum profundus (FDP), both in a common synovial sheath (in ulnar bursa).
  • 1 Median nerve
  • 1 Flexor pollicis longus (FPL) with its synovial sheath (in radial bursa).

Medial superficial slip of flexor retinaculum (called volar carpal ligament):

  • Volar carpal ligament forms the "Guyon's canal"
  • Guyon's canal contains ulnar nerve and vessels.

Lateral deep slip of flexor retinaculum:

  • Flexor carpi radialis (FCR) tendon is the only content.

Flexor retinaculum has 4 attachments:

  • Medially:
    • Pisiform
    • Hook of the hamate
  • Laterally:
    • Tubercles of scaphoid
    • Trapezium

questions.text: Which of the following is not present in the fourth compartment of the extensor retinaculum?
questions.solution:
Extensor pollicis longus is not present in the fourth compartment of the extensor retinaculum. Posterior interosseous nerve and anterior interosseous artery are present in the fourth compartment.

Extensor retinaculum attachments:

  • Medially - Pisiform and triquetral.
  • Laterally - Anterior border of the radius.

Related Pearl: Structures Passing through the Extensor Retinaculum Compartments

Extensor Retinaculum

Compartments

Structures passing through them

I

Abductor pollicis longus (APL)

Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)

II

Extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL)

Extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB)

III

Extensor pollicis longus (EPL)

IV

Extensor digitorum (ED)

Extensor indicis (EI)

Posterior interosseous nerve

Anterior interosseous artery 

V

Extensor digiti minimi (EDM)

VI

Extensor carpi ulnaris (ECU)

questions.text: Which of the following is false about dorsal digital expansion?

choices.text: Base of the expansion is at the MCP
Wing tendons refer to the attachment of extensor digitorum
The central slip of the extensor tendon is attached to the base of middle phalanx
The collateral slips are attached to the base of distal phalanx

questions.solution:
Wing tendons refer to the insertion of lumbricals and interossei to the corners of the dorsal digital expansion or simply extensor expansion.

Dorsal digital expansion/ Extensor expansion:

  • Formation: By extensor tendons expanding "extensor expansion"
  • Location: Back of digits "dorsal digital expansion"
  • Extensors making the expansion: ED, EPL (extensor digitorum and extensor pollicis longus)
  • Muscles joining the expansion: EDM, EI, EPB (extensor digiti minimi, extensor indicis, and extensor pollicis brevis)

Extensor expansion triangular hood attachments: (The shape of expansion)

  • Apex: Distal phalanx
  • Central region: Middle phalanx (in the thumb, attached to proximal phalanx)
  • Corner of the base: Sides of MCP joint (in the thumb, attached to muscles)
  • Extensor hood: Lumbrical, interossei, and extensor digitorum muscles (in the thumb, the adductor pollicis and abductor pollicis brevis muscles)

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in one of her fingers. Kanavel's sign is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Kanavel's sign is suggestive of tenosynovitis.

Clinically, it can distinguish infectious tenosynovitis from superficial or localized abcess.

Kanavel's sign has the following effects - 

  1. Tenderness over affected tendon
  2. Fusiform swelling over affected tendon
  3. The affected finger is in slight flexion
  4. Pain on passive extension of the affected finger

questions.text: An infection of the finger as in the image below is most likely to spread to which of the following spaces?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an infection, paronychia, of the middle finger. It can spread into the mid-palmar space.

Infections of the:

  • Ring and middle finger spread into the mid-palmar space
  • Index finger to thenar space
  • Little finger spread to ulnar bursa and mid palmar space.

Related Pearl: Spaces of Hand

Spaces of hand

Features

Extensions/communications

Clinical correlation

Thenar space

Located under lateral half of hollow of palm.

Contains FPL, other flexor tendons of index finger

Proximally: limited by anterior and posterior walls of carpal tunnel

Distally: communicates with 1st web space through 1st lumbrical

Infection: from radial bursa / synovial sheath of index finger

Drainage: incision in web space of thumb

Midpalmar space

Under medial half of hollow of palm

Contains flexor tendons of medial 3 digits

Proximally: continuous with forearm space of parona

Distally: continuous with medial 3 web spaces through medial 3 lumbricals.

Infection: ulnar bursa is inlet, lumbrical canals are outlet.

Drainage: incision in medial 2 web spaces

Ulnar bursa

Common synovial flexor sheath envelops tendons of FDS, FDP

Proximally: extend into forearm 2.5cm proximal to flexor retinaculum

Distally: extends in palm upto midshaft of metacarpals.

Medially: continuous with synovial sheath of little finger

Drainage: incision on radial margin of hypothenar eminence

Radial bursa

Synovial flexor sheath for FPL

Proximally:

extend into forearm 2.5cm proximal to flexor retinaculum

Distally: continuous with digital synovial sheaths of thumb

Drainage: medial margin of thenar eminence

Forearm space of parona

Facial interval below flexor tendons of distal part of forearm

Proximally: continuous with intermuscular spaces of forearm

Distally: reaches level of wrist

Infection: from ulnar bursa

Drainage: vertical incision on distal part of forearm

questions.text: Which of the following is not the content of the mid-palmar space?
questions.solution:
The 1st lumbrical is not a content of the mid-palmar space.

The 1st lumbrical is related to the FDP (flexor digitorum profundus) tendon of the index (2nd finger). Thus, it lies in the thenar space.

The 2nd, 3rd, and 4th lumbricals are related to the FDP of the middle (3rd finger), ring (4th finger), and little (5th finger) respectively. Thus, they lie in the mid-palmar space.

questions.text: A patient with the following infection in the finger requires incision and drainage as it can lead to all of the following except:

choices.text: Necrosis of the whole of phalanx
Septic arthritis of the distal interphalangeal joint

questions.solution:
The given image shows an infection of the pulp space of the finger or whitlow. It requires incision and drainage because when neglected, whitlow can lead to necrosis of the distal 4/5th of the terminal phalanx. It does not cause necrosis of the entire phalanx because the proximal 1/5th escapes as in this part the artery does not cross the fibrous septa.

The pulp space of fingers contains subcutaneous fat arranged in tight compartments. These compartments are formed by fibrous septa extending from the skin to the periosteum of the terminal phalanx.

Whitlow or pulp space infections are treated by a lateral incision and drainage. Its complications are: 

  • Ischemic necrosis of the distal 4/5th of terminal phalanx due to vessel occlusion.
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Flexor tenosynovitis
  • Septic arthritis of DIP (distal interphalangeal joint)
